author: By Cade Metz and Kate Conger
title: Uber, After Years of Trying, Is Handing Off Its Self-Driving Car Project
description: Company executives once said having cars that can drive on their own would be a salvation for their business. But the effort turned into a legal and financial headache.
content: Uber, which spent hundreds of millions of dollars on a self-driving car project that executives once believed was a key to becoming profitable, is handing the autonomous vehicle effort over to a Silicon Valley start-up, the companies said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: In His Autobiography, the College Basketball Giant John Thompson Is Plainspoken and Profound
description: The longtime Georgetown coach, who died in August at 78, writes about his upbringing and his remarkable career in “I Came as a Shadow.”
content: “I’m six feet 10 inches tall,” the longtime Georgetown basketball coach John Thompson writes in his posthumously published autobiography. “I have a large mouth, a big head and a deep voice. I naturally make a big noise. Not only am I Black, but I have dark skin. My feet are big, my body is big. Sometimes I’m loud, but I’m loud because I’m composed of big things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: After a Hard Year, Holiday Commercials Get Real
description: Tear-jerker scenes and reminders of the coronavirus pandemic are part of a not-so-cheery seasonal ad blitz.
content: For television viewers, the holiday season means commercials filled with rosy-cheeked Santas, computer-generated polar bears and brand-new cars festooned with big red bows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: What Were the Jets Thinking?
description: The Jets looked to have their first win of the season sewn up. But a decision to send an all-out blitz against the Raiders on the final play handed Las Vegas the game-winning touchdown.
content: The dumbest N.F.L. play call ever? Some people think it came on Sunday, and it seems to have cost the Jets’ defensive coordinator, Gregg Williams, his job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: The Suburbs Helped Elect Biden. Can They Give Democrats the Senate, Too?
description: Some Atlanta suburbs that used to be “blood red” went blue in November. But Democrats need strong turnout in January, not just disaffected Republicans seeking to give Trump one final defeat.
content: DECATUR, Ga. — President Trump bet his re-election on a very specific vision of the American suburb: a 2020 edition of Mayfield from “Leave It to Beaver” in which residents are white, resent minorities, and prioritize their economic well-being over all other concerns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Remembering Rafer Johnson in a Long Year of Lost Sports Legends
description: The death of the Olympic track star hit our columnist particularly hard because of the connection to him from his early years and the toll of other titans who died this year.
content: Death stalks us always. It is a bitter truth we tend to shove from our thoughts in typical times. But during a pandemic, we cannot. It is before our eyes daily, in the news, in our communities, sometimes in our homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Hears Holocaust Survivors’ Cases Against Hungary and Germany
description: The justices struggled to decide whether a 1976 law that bars most suits against other nations allows Jewish victims to sue over the theft of their property.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court, wary in the past of cases concerning conduct by and against foreigners that took place abroad, heard arguments on Monday over whether American courts have a role in deciding whether Hungary and Germany must pay for property said to have been stolen from Jews before and during World War II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Habits Have You Started or Left Behind in 2020?
description: What new routines have you established during the pandemic? What habits and pastimes have you given up or modified?
content: What are your daily and weekly routines — activities that you repeat without even thinking? Consider what you typically do from the moment you wake up in the morning until the time you fall asleep at night. What purpose do these routines serve in your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen
title: A Rare Pandemic Silver Lining: Mental Health Start-Ups
description: Using teletherapy, metrics and matching algorithms, entrepreneurs are focusing on addressing aspects of the mental health care system that they view as broken.
content: Ariela Safira was on a mission. Shaken by the attempted suicide of a friend during her freshman year at Stanford University in 2013, Ms. Safira sought to understand the opaque mental health care system. She soon learned of the shortage of qualified therapists and, even where they are more plentiful, of the hurdles to obtaining care. Although a computer science and math major, she eventually enrolled in a clinical psychology graduate program at Columbia University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Chris Young Heads Home, and the Mets Keep Waiting
description: The Mets were in the hunt for one of the top general manager candidates in the game, but the ability to stay in Texas was something Steven Cohen could never match.
content: All the billions in the world, apparently, cannot change one stubborn truth about modern baseball: everything takes time. The Mets will have a general manager someday, and the new owner, Steven A. Cohen, will surely find players to take a small slice of his fortune. But for now, the industry is adjusting its batting gloves, stepping off the rubber and checking the defensive-alignment card tucked inside its cap. So we wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Chick-fil-A Accuses Poultry Suppliers of Price Fixing
description: The fast-food chain has named Tyson Foods, Perdue Farms and other producers in a lawsuit, which carries the latest allegations of price fixing in the industry.
content: Chick-fil-A, the company that says it invented the chicken sandwich, has accused more than a dozen poultry suppliers in a federal lawsuit of inflating prices on billions of dollars of chicken that it bought.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: L.G.B.T. stands for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender. The abbreviation appeared in Will Nediger’s puzzle on Wednesday, Nov 2. at 10-Across, and it has so far made 21 appearances in the New York Times Crossword.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Indoor Dining May Be Banned Again, Threatening Many N.Y.C. Restaurants
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced a new restrictions model that could end indoor dining in the city as early as next week.
content: Since the pandemic forced most New York City businesses to shut down nine months ago, the restaurant industry has warned that it was facing a crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Schaverien
title: In Australia’s Deadly Year for Shark Attacks, a Surfer Lives to Tell the Tale
description: After being bitten by a great white in South Australia, the victim managed to paddle ashore and walk nearly 1,000 feet for help. He said the attack “was like being hit by a truck.”
content: A surfer who was mauled by a great white shark in remote waters in Australia managed to swim ashore and walk nearly 1,000 feet to seek help, a “remarkable” feat, according to one of the paramedics who treated him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: ‘This Is Insanity’: Start-Ups End Year in a Deal Frenzy
description: Investors are tripping over one another to give hot start-ups money. DoorDash and Airbnb are going public. The good times are baaack.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Hopin, a virtual events start-up in London, had seven employees and was valued at $38 million at the beginning of the year. Johnny Boufarhat, the company’s chief executive, wasn’t planning on raising more money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Police in Indonesia Kill 6 Followers of Hard-Line Cleric
description: The authorities said the men, adherents of the Muslim cleric Rizieq Shihab, were shot and killed after they attacked officers in an unmarked car that had been following them.
content: Six followers of the divisive Indonesian cleric Rizieq Shihab were shot and killed by the police on the outskirts of Jakarta early Monday after what the authorities described as an attack on officers who were tailing the men as part of an investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Best Songs of 2020
description: Tracks responding to real-time events and a spectrum of moods captured the hodgepodge feelings of life in lockdown.
content: No short list can sum up the plenitude of remarkable songs that appear every year, from commercial bangers to standout album tracks to one-time digital apparitions. So don’t treat this as a ranking. Enjoy it as a playlist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Elizabeth J. McCormack, Innovative Educator, Dies at 98
description: A former nun, she transformed Manhattanville College as its president before becoming a philanthropic adviser to major foundations and the Rockefellers.
content: Elizabeth J. McCormack, a former Roman Catholic nun who was the catalyst for sweeping changes at Manhattanville College in the 1960s and ’70s, and who later advised major foundations on philanthropic strategies, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australia Gears Up for the Great Koala Count, Using Drones, Droppings and Dogs
description: The marsupials are not easy to find, or count accurately, so officials will deploy new methods.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — One would think that koalas are easy to find and count. They’re large. They’re fluffy. They’re mostly immobile since they tend to sleep for about 20 hours a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Another Month on a Warming Planet: Record-Hot November
description: European scientists reported that November’s global temperatures were the highest ever, surpassing the previous record, set in 2016 and 2019.
content: Last month was the hottest November on record, European researchers said Monday, as the relentlessly warming climate proved too much even for any possible effects of cooler ocean temperatures in the tropical Pacific Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Mitchell
title: ‘Mank’ and Politics: What Really Happened in 1934 California
description: In the Netflix drama, Hollywood gets involved in the race for governor. But while that’s based in fact, history didn’t exactly go down that way.
content: David Fincher’s new Netflix drama “Mank” explores how Herman J. Mankiewicz came to co-write the celebrated screenplay for “Citizen Kane.” Why did he stick with it despite enormous pressure to drop the project? In the film’s telling, one of his primary motivations is the author Upton Sinclair’s race for governor of California in 1934, and how it was sabotaged by the MGM producer Irving Thalberg and the media baron William Randolph Hearst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Gabriela Hearst Unveiled as Chloé’s New Artistic Director
description: The Uruguayan-born, New York-based designer will continue as creative director at her namesake brand alongside her new role.
content: And so a new era begins at Chloé. Less than a week after the departure of Natacha Ramsay-Levi following a four year tenure, the French fashion house announced Gabriela Hearst as its new artistic director, effective immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Hailey Fuchs
title: Georgia Republicans push back as Trump calls for a special legislative session.
description: Officials in Georgia pushed back on Sunday against President Trump as he continued repeating baseless allegations questioning the integrity of the election and called for a special session of the State Legislature with the aim of overturning his loss.
content: Officials in Georgia pushed back on Sunday against President Trump as he continued repeating baseless allegations questioning the integrity of the election and called for a special session of the State Legislature with the aim of overturning his loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Among Sparkling Wines, the Other Half Lives Pretty Well
description: Consumers focus on Champagne, but in the bubbly universe many stars offer distinctive and delicious versions of their own.
content: The Wine School assignment over the last month was simple: Drink sparkling wines in three different styles from three different regions — the Loire Valley of France, Trento in Italy and the Penedès in Spain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Trump’s Pressure Campaign in Georgia
description: Trump turns up the heat on the governor, but the governor isn't playing ball: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Trump’s Act V continues to play out in Georgia, while Biden names another key member of his health policy team. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Fishermen’ help fight mental health problems in Britain during the pandemic.
description: The past few weeks have been busy for the Bearded Fishermen, a mental health charity in England. With the country just emerging from a second lockdown, the group has seen a measurable uptick in calls for support and an increasing need for its crisis services as the community grapples with the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: The past few weeks have been busy for the Bearded Fishermen, a mental health charity in England. With the country just emerging from a second lockdown, the group has seen a measurable uptick in calls for support and an increasing need for its crisis services as the community grapples with the fallout of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Bronx vs. Manhattan
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: The Democratic Party’s biggest problem today is its struggle to win over working-class voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Pressure on California hospitals is still mounting fast, Newsom says.
description: Hospitals across California have continued to fill rapidly to dangerous levels as state and local officials try to dampen the explosive spread of the coronavirus in the state, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.
content: Hospitals across California have continued to fill rapidly to dangerous levels as state and local officials try to dampen the explosive spread of the coronavirus in the state, Gov. Gavin Newsom said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Being Boba Fett: Temuera Morrison Discusses ‘The Mandalorian’
description: Morrison, a veteran of the “Star Wars” film franchise, talks about his role as the fearsome bounty hunter on the Disney+ series “The Mandalorian.”
content: It’s been nearly 40 years since moviegoers saw Boba Fett, the fearsome bounty hunter of the original “Star Wars” saga, take an ill-fated tumble into the Great Pit of Carkoon, where he was presumed to have been devoured by the Sarlacc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: The Most Tender Short Ribs, the Most Satisfying Soup
description: Left with some spare short ribs, J. Kenji López-Alt made them sing in a Taiwanese beef noodle soup.
content: Hmm, I thought to myself as I did an emoji-quality chin scratch by the light of the refrigerator door late one night last year. Hmm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Birth Defects Tied to Higher Cancer Risk
description: Major birth defects are associated with an increased risk for cancer in childhood. New research suggests the risk persists into adulthood.
content: People born with birth defects have a higher risk for cancer throughout life, researchers report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Marie Tae McDermott
title: California Lockdowns Go Into Effect
description: Monday: Southern California, the San Joaquin Valley and the Bay Area are now under stay-at-home orders. Also: Los Angeles’s outdoor dining ban.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bob Dylan Sells His Songwriting Catalog in Blockbuster Deal
description: Universal Music purchased his entire songwriting catalog of more than 600 songs in what may be the biggest acquisition ever of a single act’s publishing rights.
content: Bob Dylan’s memoir “Chronicles: Volume One” opens in 1962 with the signing of his first music publishing deal — a contract for the copyrights of the budding songwriter’s work. The terms of that agreement, brokered by Lou Levy of Leeds Music Publishing, met young Dylan’s approval.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu, Juliana Kim, Jo Corona and Amr Alfiky
title: ‘It Makes Me Angry’: These Are the Jobless in a City Filled With Wealth
description: Pandemic job losses have disproportionately hurt low-paid service workers who tend to be poor and people of color. In this New York neighborhood, hope is slipping away.
content: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood is out of work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Lee Beyer
title: When You Can’t Go Home for the Holidays
description: A family holds tight to tradition in the face of the hardest year.
content: In my family, going home for Christmas means driving from Texas to Alabama with my husband and two young daughters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Steaks Grown From Human Cells Spark Interest and Outrage
description: An artist project offering an absurdist take on the lab-grown meat industry triggers a debate and backlash in London.
content: The installation of steak grown from human cells at the Design Museum in London was intended to criticize the meat industry’s rising use of living cells from animals. It ended up triggering a roiling debate about bioethics and the pitfalls of artistic critique.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jed Kolko and Toni Monkovic
title: The Places That Had the Biggest Swings Toward and Against Trump
description: Education was a key dividing line, but other things mattered, too.
content: With most of the slow-to-report votes tallied, we finally have a clearer picture of last month’s presidential results. Despite the high polarization in the country that carried over to the reaction to the results — with 70 percent to 80 percent of Republicans still saying they disbelieve that Joe Biden won — in some respects the vote itself was less polarized than in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: How the Virus Swept Through a Corner of Queens
description: During the spring, as the first wave of the coronavirus caused havoc, five neighborhoods were the hardest-hit place in the country.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Montepulciano d’Abruzzo: Highly Popular but Little Known
description: It’s made of Italy’s second-most widely planted red grape, and the wines are priced to go. How come they don’t get more respect?
content: It’s time to dig in. In the Northeast, the cold and dark of winter are arriving, made even chillier by the unrelenting Covid-19 pandemic. The holidays, at least, will be festive in 2020’s own peculiar way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: The Kremlin Is Offering Russians Free Vaccines, but Will They Take Them?
description: Distrust of the government is so widespread that 59 percent of Russians say they have no intention of getting a shot.
content: MOSCOW — Aleksei Zakharov, a Moscow economics professor, got the Russian coronavirus vaccine injected into his upper arm over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Recipes You Won’t Soon Forget
description: Buttermilk marble cake, seafood pancakes, lemon-caper pork chops: You may remember what you cook in this time for many years to come.
content: It’s funny, the kitchen rhythms I’ve fallen into during the pandemic, and the dishes I’ll forever associate with this time. So many seafood pancakes. So many ham and Swiss sandwiches. So much hollandaise sauce — with scallops and bo ssam, no less. All those bricks of tofu cubed and fried or planked and baked. A year ago, I barely ever cooked tofu at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Achal Prabhala, Arjun Jayadev and Dean Baker
title: Want Vaccines Fast? Suspend Intellectual Property Rights
description: Otherwise, there won’t be enough shots to go around, even in rich countries.
content: As some reports would have it, this is the beginning of the end. Three coronavirus vaccines have posted excellent results, with more expected to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: California, Vaccines, Georgia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: arrant
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: After Grand Theft Auto and Minecraft, Balenciaga: The Video Game?
description: The fashion house has created a game to showcase its latest collection, and everyone can play.
content: The year is 2031. Cities are concrete jungles crossed by flying buses that can twist in space and populated by avatars in oversize puffers and shredded jeans that resemble antique draperies over windows to interior worlds. They gesture toward posters promoting a secret rave in a watery wood that leads to a red rock desert where a woman in silver armor pulls a sword from a stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: 5 Highlights of New York Mayor’s Race, as Spike Lee Weighs In
description: Ray McGuire grabbed attention with a campaign launch video, as New Yorkers get to know the candidates who have not run for office before.
content: With more than a dozen candidates running for mayor of New York City, it can be difficult to stand out. A powerful ad can help — especially if it features Spike Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Austrian Cake Sparkles at the Party
description: Punch cakes from the Vienna Cookie Company are inspired by punschkrapferl, a liquor-soaked petit four.
content: Move over, macaron. These celebratory little Viennese cakes beg for bubbly alongside. They’re new from Heidi Riegler’s Vienna Cookie Company in Baldwin, N.Y. Called punschkrapferl or punch cakes, they’re the Austrian take on petits fours, with liquor-soaked cake sandwiching fillings of jam and chocolate, glazed on the outside and blinged with a bit of gold leaf. They come in a rainbow of flavors— cherry, orange and spiced rum — seven in each silver tin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: It’s Time to Scare People About Covid
description: Our public messaging about the virus should explain the real costs — in graphic terms — of catching the virus.
content: I still remember exactly where I was sitting decades ago, during the short film shown in class: For a few painful minutes, we watched a woman talking mechanically, raspily through a hole in her throat, pausing occasionally to gasp for air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Koblin
title: MSNBC Names Rashida Jones as President, Succeeding Phil Griffin
description: Ms. Jones, currently a senior vice president at the network, will become the highest-ranking Black woman in the TV news industry.
content: MSNBC was already preparing for one momentous presidential transition next year. Now the 24-hour cable channel and home to liberal stars like Rachel Maddow is about to take on a second.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: In Debate, Loeffler Won’t Acknowledge Trump Lost Election
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 7, 2020.
content: “The president’s statements are false. They are misinformation. They are stoking anger and fear among his supporters — and hell, I voted for him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Is American Dietetics a White-Bread World? These Dietitians Think So
description: A new generation of practitioners says the profession pays inadequate attention to different kinds of diets, body types and lives.
content: Long before she decided to help others eat better by becoming a dietitian, Jessica Wilson learned that the profession was unlikely to offer much to people like her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Walcott
title: Fishing by Lantern on an Island in Kenya
description: On Lake Victoria, attracting baitfish with lanterns extends as far back as anyone can remember. But overfishing may jeopardize the tradition.
content: As the sun sets over the waters of Lake Victoria, the soft sound of the lapping waves is drowned out by the hum of motors. Squinting, I can see them on the horizon, the tiny boats splitting the oranges and blues of the twilight sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: New York Philharmonic Musicians Agree to Years of Pandemic Pay Cuts
description: Anticipating a long road to financial recovery, the orchestra has decided on cuts that will gradually lessen.
content: The New York Philharmonic, battered by a pandemic that will keep its concert hall dark for at least 15 months, announced on Monday that its musicians had agreed to a four-year contract that includes substantial salary cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Pat Patterson, a Wrestling Star Who Came Out, Dies at 79
description: He delighted his fans, especially in villain roles. When he announced in 2014 that he was gay, they remained loyal.
content: Pat Patterson, the first major wrestling star to announce that he was gay, died on Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: A Powerful Reporter Got Away With Sexual Misconduct for Decades. His Paper, and His Union, Looked the Other Way.
description: Michael Fuoco was a bigfoot reporter with a fiery personality and a reputation for harassing young women. No one seemed to want to rein him in.
content: As the American news business shrank and struggled over the past decade, a new wave of labor activism caught fire. A younger generation of labor leaders rose up and offered a powerful and progressive vision: They would be transparent, sensitive to issues of racism and sexism and truly accountable to workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida’s fired virus data manager says the police seized her computer.
description: Police officers seized the computer, cellphone and hard drives of Rebekah D. Jones, an outspoken critic of Florida’s handling of coronavirus data,  Ms. Jones said.
content: Police officers seized the computer, cellphone and hard drives of Rebekah D. Jones, an outspoken critic of Florida’s handling of coronavirus data,  Ms. Jones said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: How to Return to Campus Safely: Test, Then Test Again
description: Some colleges are using lessons from the fall to bring back more students in spring
content: The fall semester has been hell for most colleges — canceled classes, dorm closures, outbreaks and deaths. No one wants a repeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julius Krein
title: Trump Needed the ‘Boneheads’ More Than He Knew
description: Populists cast themselves in opposition to technocratic expertise — but they ultimately rely upon it.
content: Donald Trump’s public feuding with his own senior appointees is a signature aspect of his tumultuous presidency. The Fed chairman, Jerome Powell, and his colleagues are “boneheads”; a former national security adviser (John Bolton) is a “wacko”; and his former secretary of state (Rex Tillerson) is “dumb as a rock.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Javier C. Hernández
title: China’s ‘King of Vaccines,’ a partner to AstraZeneca, is plagued by scandal.
description: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with cash.
content: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Trading Box Office for Streaming, but Stars Still Want Their Money
description: If studios are no longer trying to maximize ticket sales, what will that mean for often lucrative pay packages tied to a film’s performance in theaters?
content: LOS ANGELES — Last month, Warner Bros. quietly approached Hollywood’s two biggest talent agencies, William Morris Endeavor and Creative Artists. The studio wanted to release the much-anticipated “Wonder Woman 1984” simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max on Christmas Day. And they wanted to get the film’s star, Gal Gadot, and director, Patty Jenkins, on board with the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: Dolly Parton and the Women Who Love Her
description: Sarah Smarsh talks about “She Come by It Natural,” her book about Parton and the lives of her fans.
content: Dolly Parton’s no stranger to attention, and she’s been in the news a lot lately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: A Referee Pursues Her Calling in the Men’s Game
description: Last season, Crystal Hogan was the only woman officiating games in the top level of college basketball. The question is: Why?
content: COMPTON, Calif. — There are nearly 900 officials working in the top tier of men’s college basketball, keeping order at thousands of games. They wear black-and-white striped shirts and try to keep a low profile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Behind Baker Mayfield, the Browns and Their Playoff Hopes Mature
description: With a five-touchdown outburst against a formidable A.F.C. contender, Cleveland and its stabilizing star showed a trait the franchise had lacked for almost two decades: playoff poise.
content: The Cleveland Browns’ postseason drought grew from a crabby and cranky toddler into an exasperating adolescent. After its tumultuous teens, it seems ready to say goodbye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Pantyhose and Trash Bags: How Music Programs Are Surviving in the Pandemic’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about innovations embraced by student music groups that address concerns about spreading the coronavirus.
content: Featured Article: “Pantyhose and Trash Bags: How Music Programs Are Surviving in the Pandemic” by Aishvarya Kavi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Bad Bunny’s New Album Is Billboard’s First All-Spanish No. 1
description: The Puerto Rican pop star’s latest LP, “El Último Tour del Mundo,” debuted at the top of the Billboard 200 chart. Miley Cyrus is No. 2.
content: Bad Bunny, the Puerto Rican singer, rapper and streaming megastar, has set an industry milestone with his latest album, “El Último Tour del Mundo”: It is the first LP entirely in Spanish to top the Billboard 200 album chart.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Online sales pile up, but a logjam for shipping all that stuff is looming.
description: If there was ever a year to get your holiday shopping done early, this is it. The pandemic surge has experts predicting three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure during the holiday season — about 800 million more than were delivered last year, Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari report in The New York Times.
content: If there was ever a year to get your holiday shopping done early, this is it. The pandemic surge has experts predicting three billion packages will course through the nation’s shipping infrastructure during the holiday season — about 800 million more than were delivered last year, Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari report in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Giants Outmuscle Seahawks in Season’s Biggest Upset
description: Facing Seattle on the road without their starting quarterback, the Giants picked up their fourth straight win behind a stout defense, a lot of running and no trickery.
content: At the midpoint of the Giants’ 2020 season, they had lost seven of their eight games, with four of those defeats by four or fewer points.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A Costly Quip Angers Chinese Moviegoers, and a Film Is Yanked
description: “Monster Hunter” disappeared from theaters in China after online critics labeled a snippet of dialogue — a pun about knees — racist and called for a boycott.
content: In a film scene that has roiled a segment of the Chinese moviegoing public, two American soldiers share a strange bit of banter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Anti-Vaccine Doctor Has Been Invited to Testify Before Senate Committee
description: The selection of Dr. Jane M. Orient as federal health officials are trying to promote a vaccine to end the coronavirus pandemic prompted harsh criticism from Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York.
content: WASHINGTON — A doctor who is skeptical of coronavirus vaccines and promotes the anti-malaria drug hydroxychloroquine as a Covid-19 treatment will be the lead witness at a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee hearing on Tuesday, prompting criticism from Democrats who say Republicans should not give a platform to someone who spreads conspiracy theories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: No, Kelly Loeffler didn’t wear a wire during a debate.
description: The false claim about the Georgia Republican was shared by some liberals on Twitter.
content: On Sunday, Senator Kelly Loeffler, a Republican in one of the runoff elections in Georgia next month, fielded questions and sparred with her Democratic opponent, the Rev. Raphael Warnock, in a televised debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Are Cities a Safe Place to Live During a Pandemic?
description: Dense urban centers were vilified when the pandemic struck, rekindling the age-old town vs. country debate. We asked seven experts if the backlash was warranted.
content: In the spring, as thousands of people were sickened by the coronavirus, the bodies began to pile up in one of the country’s densest urban centers: New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Who should get a shot first? Second? Third?
content: The coronavirus vaccination campaign is expected to begin in the United States within the next month, and the debate about when different groups of Americans should receive doses is heating up. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recommended that health care workers and the oldest, most vulnerable people should be first in line. Who should go next?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: How New York City Plans to Keep Children Safe as Schools Reopen
description: There will likely be more closures of individual school buildings as the amount of testing increases.
content: On Monday, New York City will reopen some of its public schools in the teeth of a worsening coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: A Bee Gees Documentary and ‘Couples Therapy’
description: “The Bee Gees: How Can You Mend A Broken Heart” debuts on HBO. And a pandemic-focused “Couples Therapy” special airs on Showtime.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 7-12. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Weiner
title: A Fake ‘War on Christmas’ and the Real Battle Against Covid
description: There are two culture wars, but only one with deadly consequences.
content: It’s the Christmas season, when the air is usually filled with the sound of carols, the jingling of cash registers and the cries of the religious right and its political bedmates complaining that a cashier who says, “happy holidays,” or an insufficiently Christmas-specific Starbucks cup constitutes an attack on their beliefs. In other words, it’s getting to be “war on Christmas” time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: Trump administration officials passed when Pfizer offered months ago to sell the U.S. more vaccine doses.
description: Before Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine was proved highly successful in clinical trials last month, the company offered the Trump administration the chance to lock in supplies beyond the 100 million doses the pharmaceutical maker agreed to sell the government as part of a $1.95 billion deal months ago.
content: Before Pfizer’s coronavirus vaccine was proved highly successful in clinical trials last month, the company offered the Trump administration the chance to lock in supplies beyond the 100 million doses the pharmaceutical maker agreed to sell the government as part of a $1.95 billion deal months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu, Juliana Kim and Jo Corona
title: A Bronx neighborhood reels with 26 percent unemployment.
description: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx are out of work.
content: More than one in four workers in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx are out of work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: An N.B.A. Veteran Turns Wisdom Into Wins, On and Off the Court
description: At 36, Andre Iguodala is on the back end of his N.B.A. career, as an elder statesman with the Miami Heat, but he’s hitting his stride in the tech world.
content: Andre Iguodala’s family members were reluctant card game participants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: David L. Lander, Squiggy on ‘Laverne & Shirley,’ Dies at 73
description: He appeared in more than 100 movies and TV projects, but was best known for his seven-year run on the popular 1970s sitcom.
content: David L. Lander, the comic actor who for seven seasons made entrance laughter inevitable as Squiggy on the ABC series “Laverne & Shirley,” died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Top Georgia election official debunks ‘ridiculous’ claims about election fraud.
description: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”
content: Late on Nov. 3, election workers in Fulton County, Georgia, heard that they would be allowed to go home for the night. So they packed uncounted ballots into suitcases and prepared to lock up for the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: As His Term Ends, Trump Faces More Questions on Payments to His Hotel
description: A civil case being pursued by the attorney general for the District of Columbia has brought renewed attention to what limits there should be on a president’s ability to profit from the office.
content: WASHINGTON — It was a month before Donald J. Trump’s inauguration, and one of his aides had a delicate question: Wasn’t there going to be a backlash when it became known that the inauguration had spent donors’ money at Mr. Trump’s hotel in Washington, even though other places would cost much less or even be free?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: In Poland, Protests Over Abortion Ban Could Revolutionize Politics
description: The government’s conservative social policies, closely tied to the Catholic Church, have met with a backlash from women hoping to change a political culture that developed after Communism fell.
content: Women have been at the heart of a protest movement that has grown and battled on Poland’s streets since October, sparked by a court decision to ban most abortions. But this was never just a one-issue protest. Something deeper is going on, and it has been building for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian
title: DoorDash and Airbnb plan to go public, and other news in the week ahead.
description: DoorDash plans to make its stock market debut on Wednesday, followed by Airbnb on Thursday. Both have raised their valuation targets significantly, part of a frenzy of tech deal making that some say resembles the dot-com mania.
content: DoorDash plans to make its stock market debut on Wednesday, followed by Airbnb on Thursday. Both have raised their valuation targets significantly, part of a frenzy of tech deal making that some say resembles the dot-com mania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Metropolitan Opera to Lock Out Stagehands as Contract Talks Stall
description: After reaching a bargaining impasse, the shuttered opera company said it would lock out the workers needed to build sets for next season’s productions.
content: In one of the most serious labor disputes to erupt in the culture world since the coronavirus pandemic halted performances around the globe, the Metropolitan Opera said on Monday that it planned to lock out its stagehands at midnight after the union representing the workers balked at the company’s demands for pay cuts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Apoorva Mandavilli and Jill Cowan
title: Trump Officials Push Ambitious Vaccine Timeline as California Locks Down
description: As cases surge and hospital beds fill up, federal officials said a vaccine could be distributed to as many as 24 million people by mid-January.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration’s top health officials outlined an ambitious timetable on Sunday for distributing the first coronavirus vaccinations to as many as 24 million people by mid-January, even as the accelerating toll of the pandemic filled more hospital beds across the United States and prompted new shutdown orders in much of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Arctic Seismic Work Will Not Hurt Polar Bears, Government Says
description: The announcement removes a major hurdle to approving a plan to hunt for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, part of a push to allow drilling there by the Trump administration.
content: The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said on Monday that a seismic survey planned for the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska this winter would have “no more than a negligible impact” on the numbers of polar bears in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: As Brexit Deadline Looms, Boris Johnson Takes Personal Control of Talks
description: With negotiators at impasse, the prime minister hopes he and European leaders can hammer out a trade deal to replace the one that expires on Dec. 31.
content: LONDON — With time running out and the gaps still wide, Prime Minister Boris Johnson took personal control of the Brexit negotiations on Monday, declaring that he would travel to Brussels later this week for a last-ditch effort to strike a trade agreement between Britain and the European Union.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: When a Family Is Fractured
description: For most people, estrangements and family rifts are a source of chronic stress that threatens “mental, social and physical well-being.”
content: Show me a family that has not been fractured — temporarily or permanently — by a fury-filled rift between two or more members and I might believe in miracles. Just about everyone I know seems to have experienced such a distressing event, often with painful psychological and sometimes physical effects that carried over to relatives who had nothing to do with the precipitating dispute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Javier C. Hernández
title: Scandal Dogs AstraZeneca’s Vaccine Partner in China
description: The British-Swedish drugmaker has joined with a huge Asian company to produce a Covid-19 vaccine in China, where shady reputations are common in the pharmaceutical industry.
content: As a government regulator sidled into a car, the Chinese pharmaceutical executive handed over a paper bag stuffed with $44,000 in cash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Dickerson and Ryan Christopher Jones
title: Three Years After Family Separation, Her Son Is Back. But Her Life Is Not.
description: Many of the migrant families separated under the Trump administration’s most controversial immigration policy have been reunited. But some are still struggling.
content: When Leticia Peren bid her 15-year-old son, Yovany, good night in a Texas Border Patrol station three years ago, he was still small enough that she, standing less than five feet tall, reached down a little when she placed her hand on his shoulder and urged him to rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Dick Allen, 78, Dies; Baseball Slugger Withstood Bigotry
description: One of the game’s best and most honored players in the 1960s and into the ’70s, he nevertheless felt racism’s sting early in his career in Philadelphia.
content: Dick Allen, who was among baseball’s leading sluggers of the 1960s and early ’70s, playing mostly with the Phillies and Chicago White Sox, but who found himself a target of Philadelphia fans in his early years with the club, an outgrowth of racial animosity, died on Monday in Wampum, Pa. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michele C. Hollow
title: How You Can Help Count and Conserve Native Bees
description: Honeybees and their problems get the most attention, but scientists are using tactics learned from bird conservation to protect American bees.
content: In the last 20 years, the rusty patched bumblebee population declined by 87 percent because of habitat loss, use of pesticides and disease. This fuzzy bee, native to the continental United States, gets its name from the rusty patch on its back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: A Michigan pastor draws fire for telling worshipers to ‘get it, get it over with.’
description: A Michigan pastor is under fire for telling his congregation to catch the coronavirus and “get it over with.”
content: A Michigan pastor is under fire for telling his congregation to catch the coronavirus and “get it over with.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Tanning Beds and Sunbathing May Raise Endometriosis Risk
description: Living in areas that are sunnier, however, lowered the risk.
content: Women who use tanning beds or who sunbathe are at increased risk for endometriosis, according to new research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Elian Peltier
title: After Botched Covid Response, U.K. Tackles Giant Vaccine Rollout
description: Britain left hospitals short of masks and gowns, and stumbled on testing and tracing, so can it vaccinate tens of millions of people in a matter of months? Experts think it can.
content: LONDON — In Bristol, a sports stadium is being converted into a temporary clinic to provide inoculations, as is a racecourse outside London. Village halls, libraries and parking lots across the country are also being quickly turned into makeshift vaccination centers, with the government enlisting military planners for advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in December
description: Our streaming picks for December, including ‘The Prom,’ ‘Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,’ and ‘Your Honor.’
content: Every month, streaming services in Australia add a new batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for December.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Federal pandemic aid package ‘leaves a ton on the table.’
description: The $908 billion bipartisan aid package that is gaining support in Congress will not solve all of the nation’s economic problems, but economists say that the federal government should pass it anyway.
content: The $908 billion bipartisan aid package that is gaining support in Congress will not solve all of the nation’s economic problems, but economists say that the federal government should pass it anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Velsey
title: Finding Community Even in a Pandemic
description: A former priest settles in nicely at Stonewall House, an L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly senior housing development in Fort Greene.
content: Bill Meehan moved into Stonewall House, an affordable, L.G.B.T.Q.-friendly senior housing development in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, early this year, when it was not exactly an ideal time to get to know one’s neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Nick Corasaniti
title: Georgia Recertifies Election Results, Affirming Biden’s Victory
description: The move was the latest blow to President Trump’s attempts to subvert the election results. But battles over the process of voting in Georgia are likely to continue.
content: ATLANTA — Georgia election officials on Monday recertified the results of the state’s presidential race after another recount reaffirmed Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory over President Trump, the third time that results showed that Mr. Trump had lost the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Qureshi
title: ‘A Suitable Boy’ Finally Finds Its Perfect Match: Mira Nair
description: The filmmaker’s acclaimed and controversial adaptation of the landmark novel, the BBC’s first prime-time drama with an almost entirely Indian cast, comes to American TV this week.
content: When “A Suitable Boy” was published in 1993, the 1,349-page tome about post-Independence India, written by Vikram Seth, became one of the longest English-language novels in print. Superlative reviews around the world ensured its place in the door-stopping canon of modern literary classics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: California Men Declare Themselves Makers of Pine Mountain Monolith
description: Four artist-fabricators say they made the mysterious manifestation in stainless steel that sprang up in Atascadero. Meanwhile, two others rise.
content: For the first time, someone has taken credit for erecting one of the monoliths that have popped up in the last few weeks, riveting the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Why Are Pandas Covering Themselves With Horse Manure?
description: Researchers in China spent a decade studying this question.
content: Last Wednesday, Aleah Bowie, a wildlife ecologist and animal behavior expert, received an interview request by email that made her do a serious double take.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: Christmas Trees — an Elusive Bit of Happiness for Canadians
description: There’s been a run on Christmas trees as Canadians, trapped inside because of the pandemic, try, in record numbers, to shoehorn joy into their lives.
content: TORONTO — Scott Lunau was steering apple pickers onto his farm in mid-November when a customer asked if it was too early to cut down a Christmas tree. He scrambled out to the barn to find the wrapping machine and netting needed to tie up a tree like a package, ready for a roof rack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Bernstein
title: Covid-19 Dealt a Blow to Working Women. Can We Emerge Stronger?
description: As we adapt to a new normal at the office, let’s put some outmoded norms to rest.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Visa and Mastercard to Investigate Financial Ties to Pornhub
description: The payment companies said they would investigate financial links after The New York Times reported that videos on Pornhub depict child abuse.
content: Visa and Mastercard said they would investigate their financial links to MindGeek, the parent company of the adult website Pornhub, after the New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof reported that the website included videos of child abuse and nonconsensual sexual violence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lifestyles of the ‘More Famous Than Rich’
description: This entrepreneur is taking on power and money in Hollywood with a new business model for celebrities — including the ones who’ve been forgotten or canceled.
content: Steven Galanis is helping celebrities get into the gig economy. He launched his company, Cameo, three years ago as a marketplace for the famous (and not-so-famous) to sell personalized shout-outs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: How Black People Learned Not to Trust
description: Concerns about vaccination are unfortunate, but they have historical roots.
content: It would appear that the people in America hit hardest by Covid-19 — Black people — are also the group most leery about the prospects of a vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wahid Hanna
title: Biden Says No More Coddling Dictators. OK, Here’s Where to Start.
description: The United States has been far too lenient with Egypt’s brutal dictator.
content: President-elect Joe Biden has pledged to put democracy back on the agenda after four years of President Trump’s unapologetic coddling of dictators. Mr. Biden has promised to host a gathering of the world’s democracies to demonstrate his commitment to democratic values both abroad and at home. But will Mr. Biden go beyond rhetoric and gestures to making concrete policy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Russell Brand
title: Brexit: What Were We Thinking?!
description: Don’t blame working-class people for voting to leave the European Union. Blame the party that betrayed them.
content: This is an article from Turning Points, a special section that explores what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexi Pappas
title: I Achieved My Wildest Dreams. Then Depression Hit.
description: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.
content: What if athletes and coaches were trained to look for depression just as vigilantly as they’d be watching for a hamstring pull? In the Op-Ed video above, Alexi Pappas, who lives in Los Angeles, argues that we should view mental health and physical health as equally important and as treatable as a torn ACL. She would know. She’s a record-setting runner who raced at the 2016 Olympics in Rio but came crashing down after she experienced clinical depression soon after.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘It Has All Gone Too Far’
description: Why one Republican election official in Georgia is speaking out against President Trump’s baseless claims of voting fraud.
content: The state of the 2020 U.S. election is, still, not a settled matter in Georgia. For weeks, conservatives have been filing lawsuits in state and federal courts in an effort to decertify results that gave a victory to Joe Biden. On Twitter, President Trump has been making unsubstantiated claims that the state has been “scammed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kit Gillet
title: Romania’s Leader Quits After His Party’s Unexpected Election Loss
description: Prime Minister Ludovic Orban expressed confidence that his National Liberal Party would win Sunday’s parliamentary election, but by Monday, he was handing in his resignation.
content: BUCHAREST, Romania — It was supposed to be a moment of victory for Romania’s prime minister, Ludovic Orban, but after his party suffered an unexpected loss in parliamentary elections on Sunday, Mr. Orban resigned from office Monday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Clymer
title: Paul Sarbanes, 87, Dies; Maryland Senator Fought Accounting Fraud
description: Early in his career, he introduced the first article of impeachment against Richard Nixon. Decades later, he co-wrote legislation in response to corporate scandals.
content: Former Senator Paul S. Sarbanes of Maryland, a publicity-shy lawmaker who wrote landmark legislation to curb fraudulent accounting practices that led to huge investor losses and major corporate bankruptcies in 2001 and 2002, died on Sunday in Baltimore. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Trump supporters protest Michigan’s election results outside its secretary of state’s home.
description: Supporters of President Trump on Saturday night took their anger over the results of the election from the steps of the state Capitol to a quiet neighborhood in Detroit, Mich., where Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson lives.
content: Supporters of President Trump on Saturday night took their anger over the results of the election from the steps of the state Capitol to a quiet neighborhood in Detroit, Mich., where Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: An Autistic Man Is Killed, Exposing Israel’s Festering Police Brutality Problem
description: The police killing of a disabled Palestinian fueled nationwide protests. But the authorities have failed to rein in the use of excessive force, which has a long history.
content: JERUSALEM — The school for the mentally disabled in Jerusalem’s Old City made a point of preparing its Palestinian students for interactions with the Israeli police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: People across Australia celebrate a return to (almost) normal.
content: People across Australia celebrated “Freedom Day,” when months of tough coronavirus restrictions eased in the lead-up to Christmas and summer in the Southern Hemisphere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Iredale
title: Glamour Portraits for the Nurses of Mount Sinai
description: The designer Rebecca Moses turns a quarantine art project into a gift of thanks and tribute.
content: “There’s nothing fashionable — ever — about being in a hospital,” said Linda Valentino, the vice president and chief nursing officer at Mount Sinai Health System.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Schwartz
title: Xavier Becerra Brings Environmental Justice to Forefront
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s choice to run the Department of Health and Human Services is the first state attorney general to create an environmental justice bureau.
content: Martha Romero felt that she had to send her daughters to safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Trump Administration Declines to Tighten Soot Rules, Despite Link to Covid Deaths
description: Health experts say the E.P.A. decision defies scientific research showing that particulate pollution contributes to tens of thousands of premature deaths annually.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday declined to tighten controls on industrial soot emissions, disregarding an emerging scientific link between dirty air and Covid-19 death rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Dutch Panel for Looted Art Claims Must Change Course, Report Finds
description: A review commissioned by the Dutch culture minister found that the country’s art restitution panel showed too little empathy to victims of Nazi aggression and sided too often with museums.
content: AMSTERDAM — For years, the Netherlands was heralded as a leader in the effort to remedy the injustice of Nazi looting during World War II. It was praised for taking action to research stolen art and return it to its rightful owners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: Coronavirus Apps Show Promise but Prove a Tough Sell
description: Technology to alert people exposed to the virus could slow transmission, pilot studies show, but only if people and states sign up. So far, most haven’t.
content: Last spring, Apple and Google launched an ambitious effort to harness technology in the fight against Covid-19, building a powerful smartphone tool that would alert people of possible exposure to the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Catch These 15 Titles Before They Leave Netflix in December
description: The year’s end means a ton of licenses are expiring. Stream these movies and bingeable TV series while you can.
content: The end of the year means the end of licensing contracts for the streaming services, so this month’s Netflix offload is a bit of a blood bath — including not only the customary assortment of beloved movies for young and old, but also a handful of the streamer’s most binge-able and rewatchable TV series. (Dates reflect the final day of a title’s availability.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Can Body Cameras Improve Policing?
description: Body cameras are brimming with possibility, but they’re not a magic remedy for misconduct.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: ‘Take Five’ Is Impeccable. ‘Time Outtakes’ Shows How Dave Brubeck Made It.
description: An album of previously unheard recordings from the “Time Out” sessions in 1959 reveals the making of a masterpiece.
content: Listening to the alternate takes and behind-the-scenes recordings of any classic album will unravel some of its timelessness. But there’s something especially startling about hearing what went into the making of “Time Out,” the Dave Brubeck Quartet’s masterpiece, and maybe the ultimate example of a live art form being carved down and mapped out into an impeccably finished product.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Coronavirus, Brexit, Havana Syndrome: Your Monday Briefing
description: The loss, guilt and anger after an outbreak.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Is Goldman Sachs Going to Florida?
description: The Wall Street stalwart may shift some operations to the Sunshine State. It wouldn’t be alone in doing so.
content: Goldman Sachs is one of Wall Street’s best-known firms, its identity indelibly tied to New York. Yet it may move at least some parts of a major division to Florida, with costs and the pandemic in mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Kugel That’s Savory and Sweet (and Crispy, Too)
description: Yerushalmi kugel, a specialty of Jerusalem, is bound with caramel, seasoned with black pepper and filled with springy egg noodles.
content: I grew up in a family of savory kugel makers, whether my grandmother and her schmaltzy potatoes, Great-Aunt Martha with her crisp-edged egg noodle iteration or my mother and her elaborate, ever-changing vegetable combinations that veered into casserole territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.6 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.
content: This house was designed by Donald Olsen, an architect whose midcentury residences brought the hilly landscapes of Northern California indoors. The seller has made some updates, but worked to preserve the integrity of Mr. Olsen’s design.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Top Georgia Election Official Debunks ‘Ridiculous’ Claims About Election Fraud
description: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”
content: The office of Georgia’s secretary of state dedicated part of a news conference to what was called “Disinformation Monday.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Eritrea?
description: Can you find Eritrea on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about five million people.
content: Can you find Eritrea on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about five million people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $1.6 Million in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.
content: A midcentury-modern house in Lafayette, a remodeled 1967 home in Calabasas and a Victorian landmark in Nevada City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: France Infection Rate Above Target for Holiday Season
description: Jérôme Salomon, a French health official, said on Monday that new daily infections were no longer decreasing and remain particularly high among people older than 75.
content: Jérôme Salomon, a French health official, said on Monday that new daily infections were no longer decreasing and remain particularly high among people older than 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexi Pappas, Lindsay Crouse and Alexander Stockton
title: I Achieved My Wildest Dreams. Then Depression Hit.
description: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.
content: I’d spent my life training for the Olympics, but I wasn’t prepared for what came next.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 7, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 7, 2020.
content: A refer on Sunday to the Book Review misstated that the 100 Notable Books of 2020 were selected by Times critics. They were selected by Times editors.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Deciding Who Gets the Vaccine First
description: Readers discuss how those who have had the virus, the elderly and inmates should be regarded in terms of priority.
